awd_titl_txt: SNM: Scalable Nanomanufacturing of Carbon Nanotube Sheet Wrapped Carbon Fibers for Low Density and High Strength Composites
awd_abstract_narration:
Low-density, high strength composites play a critical role in a wide range of technological areas including aerospace, defense, sports, transportation, and renewable energy. One of the most important classes of low-density materials is polymer matrix composites, which are now used as primary structural materials for large airliners, and in other applications, such as wind turbines and ship structures. The use of nanostructured reinforcements in composites has been shown to improve strength, resulting in structural weight reduction, thereby leading to fuel savings and reduced ecological impact. There is an increasing interest and a strong need for nanomanufacturing technologies for making the nanostructured reinforcement materials and their composites that are scalable in throughput and quantity. Through this Scalable NanoManufacturing (SNM) award, an interdisciplinary research team will work with industry to develop a continuous nanomanufacturing process to fabricate light-weight, high-strength structural composites. Nanometer thick carbon nanotube fabric will be wrapped around individual fibers to create "fuzzy" carbon fibers to enhance their bonding strength with the surrounding polymer. The nanostructured composites will be tested to evaluate their performance under service environments. The use of the carbon nanotube fabric wrapped carbon fiber composites can potentially reduce the structural weight of aircraft, increase energy efficiency and reduce travel time.  This project will make an important contribution to the continued success of the NanoExplorer program. A large number of high school and college students will be involved in all aspects of this multi-disciplinary project. Efforts will be made to recruit students from minority and under-represented groups. 

In this project, a continuous nanomanufacturing line will be designed, built and assembled to wrap individual fibers with carbon nanotube fabric, without degrading in-plane carbon fiber properties. The concept of "false twist" will be employed to scale-up the wrapping process and make it fully automatic.  The individually wrapped "fuzzy" fibers will be subsequently consolidated to form a tow of fibers. The fiber tows will be impregnated in polymer to form prepregs, which will then be stacked and fully cured to prepare composite laminates. The laminates will be characterized for thermal stability and mechanical behavior. The nanomanufacturing process as well as the material preparation configurations will be investigated through computer simulations and models. The successful completion of the project will provide a unique scalable nanomanufacturing process to provide composites with significantly enhanced interfacial shear and compressive strength without degrading fiber tensile properties.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project developed a new nanomanufacturing process to introduce carbon nanotube sheets to wrap around carbon fibers to enhance the mechanical properties of carbon fiber composites. Polymer matrix composites, with low-density, high strength, and fatigue and corrosion resistance, are playing an increasingly critical role in a wide range of technological areas including aerospace, defense, sports, transportation, and renewable energy. These composites have high tensile strengths; but their compressive strengths are usually lower due to weak interfacial shear strengths and fiber micro-buckling. In this project, an interdisciplinary team with expertise in mechanical engineering, chemistry, and computational science has worked closely with industry, and has developed a novel process to introduce carbon nanotube sheets as interplies to further enhance the compressive strengths. The nanomanufacturing process as well as the material preparation configurations have been investigated through computer simulations and models to identify the optimum number of carbon nanotube plies to reach the maximum enhancement in mechanical properties. 

Unidirectional composite panels reinforced with such nanomanufacturing process have been fabricated, and their mechanical properties have been tested. The results show a significant enhancement in mechanical properties, up to nearly 50% from the baseline carbon fiber composites with the increase of only less than 0.02% weight increase of the composites. The new nanomanufacturing process does not introduce damage to the carbon fibers, and therefore has maintained the tensile strengths of the carbon fibers and their polymer matrix composites while enhancing dignificantly the compressive strengths.

The use of such nanostructured reinforcements in composites has potential for applications where low-density, high strengths, and high stiffness are important for structural weight reduction. The new technology has potential for applications in aircraft and electrical vehicles for fuel savings, in sports gears for increased performance, and renewable energy to contribute to a sustainable economy.

This project has also made an important contribution to the continued success of the NanoExplorer program, a high school summer research camp organized by the team. The project has made impact to a few dozen high school and college students, including female students and students in the minority and under-represented groups, who were involved in all aspects of this multi-disciplinary project.

As a result of our licensing some of our patents on carbon nanotube yarn and sheet fabrication a company has opened a 50 person laboratory near our campus to facilitate further collaboration to make impact to the society. 


Last Modified: 04/19/2022
Modified by: Hongbing Lu
